The Dharma taught by the Buddha all returns to the two truths:
First, the conventional truth; second, the ultimate truth.
The conventional truth refers to all ordinary beings, Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, bodhisattvas, tathÄgatas, up to names, meanings, wisdom, realms, karma, and fruits being mutually related.
The ultimate truth is that there is absolutely nothing to be attained in this.
As it is said, the ultimate truth is not the domain of wisdom, let alone words. Even karma and its fruits do not exist. This is the nature of the noble ones.

Therefore, in this perfection of wisdom, it is said that one should not dwell in giving, that all dharmas are without characteristics, ungraspable, indescribable, that there are no arising dharmas, no self, no attainment, no realization, no accomplishment, no coming and going, etc. This explains the ultimate truth.
It also explains the characteristics and various merits of the internal and external worlds, the mundane and supramundane, all dharmas. This establishes the conventional truth.
One should understand it in this way.
Thus have I heard shows that this sutra was spoken by the World-Honored One in his present realization, not composed by himself.
At one time means that when this sutra was spoken, at other times he also spoke innumerable sutras.
Staying in the city of Shravasti and so on are the places where it was spoken.
What is the meaning of distinguishing the place?
It is to benefit sentient beings.
How does it benefit?
It causes them to know that the Buddha has been to this place, to respect it with a pure mind, and to plant the causes of blessings.
Why are the assemblies listed at the beginning of all sÅ«tras?
It is to demonstrate the great majestic virtue of the TathÄgata, and also because the compilers certify that what they have transmitted is no different from the original teachings.
In the MahÄyÄna sÅ«tras, the World-Honored One's merits and virtues are extensively expounded. SubhÅ«ti has already given rise to pure faith in them, and therefore says it is rare, etc.
What is meant by World-Honored One here?
It is because he is able to forever eliminate the fears of the four demons.
Well-Gone means that in the ultimate truth, all dharmas are unattainable, and he has realized this himself.
TathÄgata means that after three incalculably long eons, merit and wisdom are perfected, and thus he comes to attain perfect enlightenment.
Arhat means that the afflictions, which are like enemies, have been forever destroyed.
Correct means non-erroneous, and equal means universal and complete, thus it is called correct equal enlightenment.
There are two kinds of protection and remembrance:
The TathÄgata's acceptance and causing realization is the true protection and remembrance.
Moreover, causing the transformation and teaching of immeasurable sentient beings is the foremost protection and remembrance.
Having already known the protection and remembrance, why is there entrustment?
It is for those who have not yet seen the truth.
This also has two aspects:

Those bodhisattvas will universally attain the TathÄgata's unsurpassed body and characteristics in the world. Praising and entrusting them to good and virtuous friends will cause them to look after and protect, causing the already arisen Buddha-dharmas to abide and increase. This is entrustment.
For the sake of the superior dharmas that have not yet arisen, entrusting them to cause their arising is the foremost entrustment.
Moreover, for what reason does one abandon seeing the true and praise the unseen?
It is out of pity for those who have not yet attained the superior wisdom and wholesome qualities, encouraging their minds and causing them to be courageous and diligent.

Good men and good women who have given rise to the vehicle of the bodhisattvas and so forth refer to the bodhisattvas who are being protected and entrusted with the direction towards the vehicle of the Buddha.
How should they abide and so forth. How should they abide means in what characteristics and fruits should the mind abide and aspire?
How should they practice means what practices should they cultivate in order to attain the fruits?
How should they subdue their minds means which minds should they subdue in order to purify the causes?
All dharmas have causes first and fruits later. Why is the fruit mentioned first?
It is because the fruit is praised first in order to make them delight in seeking and cultivating the causes.
Listen attentively means the mind is focused on a single object.
Good means giving rise to faith and being free from doubt regarding the meaning of suchness.
Think carefully means respectfully upholding without forgetting.
Should abide thus and so forth means that in accordance with the sequence, one should abide in the mind in such fruits, cultivate such practices, and realize such fruits.
To subdue the mind in this way is to have pure causes.
This passage reveals the four kinds of benefits associated with the mind of the bodhisattva.
What are the four?
First, boundless;
second, supreme;
third, embraced by love;
fourth, right wisdom.
What is the boundless mind?
The sutra says all kinds of sentient beings and so on.
Sentient beings refer to those who receive the breath and possess emotional awareness.
What are they again?

Namely, those born from eggs such as various birds, those born from wombs such as humans, those born from moisture such as various insects, and those born miraculously such as various gods. These four kinds each have many lineages.
Where do these sentient beings dwell and what do they take as their essence?
The sutra says those with form and those without form.
Those with form refer to those with shape.
Those without form have no shape.
Sentient beings in the three realms are all included here.
Having form refers to the twenty abodes of the desire realm and the seventeen abodes of the form realm.
Formless refers to the formless realm.
How many kinds are there?

The sÅ«tra says: If there is conceptualization, if there is no conceptualization, if it is neither with conceptualization nor without conceptualization. If there is conceptualization refers to the sphere of infinite space and the sphere of infinite consciousness, because one gives rise to the conceptualization of space and the conceptualization of consciousness.
If there is no conceptualization refers to the sphere of nothingness, because one is free from the conceptualization of a limited self, it is called without conceptualization.
If it is neither with conceptualization nor without conceptualization refers to what is included in the peak of existence.
Such a mass of sentient beings, I will all accept and embrace.
What is the supreme mind?
The sÅ«tra says: I will cause them all to enter nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder and attain liberation. What is the meaning of nirvÄá¹‡a without remainder?

It means realizing the unborn nature of all dharmas, emptiness, forever ceasing all the aggregates that are afflicted with existence, utilizing boundless rare and excellent qualities, the pure form and appearance, and the perfect adornment, widely benefiting the multitude of beings, and the wonderful activity that is inexhaustible.
What is the mind of loving-kindness and embracing?
The sÅ«tra says: Thus, although innumerable sentient beings are liberated, in reality there are no sentient beings who attain liberation.
What is the meaning of this?

Because the bodhisattva loves all sentient beings as if they were himself, when sentient beings are liberated, it is his own [liberation] and not someone else's. This is called the mind of loving-kindness and embracing.

If in the ultimate truth, upon entering the first ground and so forth, the bodhisattvas have no conception of sentient beings, because sentient beings cannot be apprehended, it is like the stream-enterer who does not give rise to the view of the transitory collection. It is not that those bodhisattvas see a single sentient being as being their own [to liberate].
What is the mind of right wisdom?
The sÅ«tra says: If there is the conception of sentient beings, one is not called a bodhisattva.
What are they called?
They are called ordinary beings.
Why is it so?
Because they must be deluded about the ultimate truth and give rise to the notions of self, sentient beings, life, and the one who grasps.
If one realizes the ultimate truth, the notions of sentient beings and so forth will definitely not arise.

Here, by the power of prajÃ±Ä, one realizes the ultimate truth, and all sentient beings are unobtainable. Out of the mind of great compassion, one always follows sentient beings, abiding in saá¹ƒsÄra and guiding them as appropriate.
These four kinds of fruits that benefit sentient beings should be cultivated with a mind that abides in the conventional truth.
The causes for perfecting these four kinds of minds should be next revealed. Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, Furthermore, SubhÅ«ti!
The bodhisattva does not abide in phenomena when practicing giving.
This name giving is endowed with the six pÄramitÄs, because giving includes the six.
What are the three?
First, the giving of material resources;
second, the giving of fearlessness;
third, the giving of the Dharma.
Among these, the giving of material things includes the perfection of giving;
the giving of fearlessness includes the perfections of morality and patience, because one does not give rise to fear towards what has been done or not done;

the giving of the Dharma includes the other three perfections, because one is diligent and not weary, one attracts various spiritual powers, and one teaches others as if there were nothing to be attained.
Or, all those perfections are explained for others, and they all become the giving of the Dharma.
What is meant by equal to that?
How does one not dwell in that?
Because one's own body always has boundless things such as suffering and happiness.
Not dwelling means that one's mind has no attachment to that, not abiding means not expecting to be repaid, and not dwelling in form, etc. means that the mind does not yearn for desirable objects.
For what other meaning does one not dwell in that?
Because if the mind dwells in oneself, one is unable to give generously, and if one has yearning and seeking, one will lose bodhi.
Furthermore, not dwelling on things refers to the giving of material resources, meaning that the giver should not be attached to the wealth that is given;
because if one gives with attachment, the mind will certainly give rise to suffering, or else one may regret it after giving.
Nowhere to abide refers to the giving of fearlessness, meaning that when bodhisattvas cultivate precepts and forbearance, they should not give rise to the mind seeking its karmic rewards.
Not dwelling on form and so forth refers to the giving of the Dharma.
The giving of the Dharma has two fruits, namely those of the present life and of future lives. One should not be greedy for either of these two.
The fruit of the present life refers to the five sense objects such as form that are used as resources.
What is this again?
It is because those who expound the Dharma are revered by the multitudes, and they make offerings with wonderful forms and so forth, music, incense, flowers, food and drink, and clothing.
The fruit of future lives refers to the objects of the Dharma.
How is it that one does not abide even in this?
If bodhisattvas realize the truth, even the Dharma body is not attained.
How does one practice the six perfections and thereby attain purity?
The sutra says: Subhuti!
Bodhisattvas should give like this, not dwelling on conceptual thoughts.
What is the meaning of this?

It means that in the ultimate truth, bodhisattvas do not give rise to thoughts of the names, meanings, and objects of the giver, receiver, and gift. This is precisely subduing the mind and thereby purifying.
Some say:
There can be the accumulation of blessings when there is a giver, etc.
Since the three factors are all false, how can there be blessings?
Alas, these words!

Because of the ultimate truth, one does not dwell on conceptual thoughts; because of conventional truth, one practices giving. In this way, the accumulation of blessings is difficult to measure, just like the vast and boundless space of the ten directions.
In the previous practice, one should praise one's blessings. What does this statement mean?
Because of subduing the mind, conceptual thoughts do not arise;
Because giving is pure only when there is no arising of conceptualization;
Because the cause of purity results in boundless blessings and virtue.
From here on, all the sutras ask questions and answer them to dispel doubts.
The blessings and virtues of upholding the true Dharma have the power of authority, and this power accomplishes all dharmas and practices.

The characteristics of the causes and effects of effortless practice are pure, the nature of the tathÄgatagarbha of all sentient beings is the realm of the buddhas, seeing the Dharma body of the buddhas is the characteristic of the Dharma realm, and nirvÄá¹‡a without abiding observes conditioned arising.
After the World-Honored One spoke, the noble SubhÅ«ti had doubts and said:

The accumulation of merit and virtue such as the marks of a hundred merits is called the World-Honored One. If one does not abide in the Dharma, how can one attain the characteristics of the essence of all buddhas?
In order to dispel this doubt, the sutra says, SubhÅ«ti!
What do you think?
Can one see the TathÄgata through the perfection of his physical characteristics?
No, one cannot.ğŸ”½Why is it so?
World-Honored One and so forth.

As for the perfection of characteristics, it is impermanent, as the sutra says All characteristics are false. The characteristics that are not characteristics are not false. What is not false is called true reality. Because it is true reality, it is called the Tathagata.
If the characteristics exist, they are deceptive.
As the sutra says One should see the Tathagata as not characterized by characteristics. This is because seeking through characteristics does not result in attainment.
If one is able to completely avoid hoping for the various fruits, and even not attain the Dharma body, yet always practices giving without abiding, then one will quickly perfect the Buddha body.
Subhuti had another doubt and said:
If the three kinds of giving are all causes of pure attainment, and the emptiness of the nature of characteristics is the true fruit, who will believe and enjoy it in the next world?
Will it not be an empty talk like that of a barren woman?
Therefore, he asks, Can there be sentient beings in the future, at the time when the Dharma is about to perish in the last fifty years, who hear these sÅ«tras and give rise to true understanding?
In order to dispel this doubt, the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti!
Do not speak like this and so forth.
The last fifty years means that the hundred-year lifespan of humans is divided into two parts:

What is the meaning of bodhisattva mahÄsattva?
One who has a determined mind in the realm of enlightenment is a bodhisattva, and one who vows to benefit all sentient beings is a mahÄsattva.
Why is he also called one who possesses moral discipline?
Because in past lives he saw innumerable Buddhas and made offerings to them all.
There are three kinds of offerings:
First, attending to their left and right;
Second, to prepare what is needed;
Third, to inquire about the essential Dharma.
Because it can be well guarded, it is called morality, meaning it can well guard the six sense faculties.
It has three aspects:
First, the morality of being able to abandon, because it abandons the ten unwholesome actions;
Second, the morality of being able to create, because it creates the wholesome actions of the factors of enlightenment;
Third, the morality of being able to progress, because it progresses towards the ultimate truth.
Why is it also called one who has merit?
Because it plants the three wholesome roots of non-greed, etc., and is honest, gentle, and has wisdom and compassion, etc., this is called merit.
Why is it also called one who has wisdom?
Because it clearly understands the non-self of both phenomena and beings.
Thus, clearly understanding is free from the eight kinds of conceptualization, because there are four kinds of conceptualizations each for phenomena and beings.

As for being free from the conceptualization of beings, the sÅ«tra says: These bodhisattvas have no conception of self, no conception of sentient beings, no conception of life, and no conception of a grasper. What is the meaning of this?
That which has a master and function is called the self.
Carefully contemplating the aggregates, there is no such essence or characteristics, therefore there is no thought of self.

Abiding in a constant nature is called sentient beings. The aggregates are impermanent and continuously flow and transform. There is not a single dharma that is a nature of abiding, therefore there is no thought of sentient beings.
As a sutra says, You are now born, grow old, and die in an instant, therefore there is no thought of life.

The revolving of the aggregates and experiencing various destinies is called grasping. There is no person in this who can grasp the destinies, abandoning the present aggregates and receiving the later aggregates, like taking off old clothes and putting on new ones.
However, relying on conventional truth, it is like a reflection appearing due to an object, the object not reaching the reflection yet the reflection appears;
Due to the former aggregates, the later aggregates continue to arise. The former not reaching the later, yet the later continues. Therefore the bodhisattva has no thought of a grasper.
This is called understanding the nature of non-self in birth.
As for the thought of dharmas being separated, the sÅ«tra says: There is no thought of dharma and also no thought of non-dharma, no thought and also no non-thought.
What does this mean again?
Because the ultimate truth is originally unborn, there is no thought of dharma. Because it is unborn, there is also no cessation, so there is no thought of non-dharma.
Because the discrimination of dharma and non-dharma is separated, there is no thought.
This statement of no thought only shows that thought does not exist, it does not mean that there is a dharma called non-thought.
Moreover, although the ultimate truth is apart from all thoughts, it is spoken of in accordance with the thoughts and words of the world. Therefore, the bodhisattva also has no non-thought.
This means understanding the nature of the non-self of dharmas.
Why is it only said that there is morality, etc.?
Upholding precepts, planting goodness, being able to give rise to deep faith, and wisdom seeing the truth gives rise to the true thought. Because all merits are included here.
Moreover, for what meaning is it said to know and see them?
In order to encourage the minds of bodhisattvas.
They say this:
I now believe and understand the TathÄgata's knowledge and vision, and should be even more diligent in cultivating all wholesome dharmas.
Why are knowledge and vision both mentioned?
In order to reveal omniscience.
What does this mean?
Omniscience is the clear and immediate awareness of all objects;
unlike inferential knowledge, which sees smoke and knows there is fire, but cannot illuminate the distinctions of various characteristics;
and unlike the fleshly eye, which sees gross and near objects, but cannot know subtle, obstructed, or distant things, but only follows what is said or like it.
If bodhisattvas give rise to the notion of self and the notion of dharmas, what faults do they incur?
Because this gives rise to the grasping of self and others.
How does the notion of self give rise to the grasping of self?
If this grasping arises, it is because of the notion.
How does the notion of dharmas give rise to the grasping of self?
Because in the aggregates of self and what belongs to self, one gives rise to the notion of dharmas and non-dharmas, not because of the non-self, earth, wood, etc.
The sÅ«tra says one should not grasp at dharmas, nor should one grasp at non-dharmas. What is the meaning of this?
Because one abandons the two extremes.
Even the nature and characteristics of dharmas should not be grasped, let alone non-dharmas which are originally without nature and characteristics.
Moreover, one without discrimination does not even grasp at good and proper dharmas, let alone bad and improper ones.
Or one may think:
Bad should not be grasped, why not grasp good?
If even good dharmas should not be grasped, why did the Buddha accumulate provisions for three incalculable eons?
Therefore the sÅ«tra says For this reason the TathÄgata always speaks of the analogy of a raft, even dharmas should be abandoned, let alone non-dharmas.
What is the meaning of this?
Just as one who wishes to cross a river should first grasp a raft, and once they reach the other shore they should abandon it and go on.

The World-Honored One is also like this. Wishing to cross the flow of suffering, one provisionally relies on the raft of provisions, transcends all fruits, and ascends to the shore of nirvÄá¹‡a. Even the causes of happiness are abandoned, let alone the causes of suffering!

As the Elephant's Back Sutra says, If one gives rise to transcendence of birth and death and realizes the realm of nirvana, the fruits of love and non-love, and the causes of Dharma and non-Dharma, all are abandoned.
Next, there is doubt:

If at the time of realization, Dharma and non-Dharma are both abandoned, why did the World-Honored One, with a single thought of corresponding right wisdom, manifest realization of all dharmas and have something to say?
In order to dispel this doubt, the sutra says, Subhuti!
What do you think?
Did the Tathagata attain anuttara-samyak-sambodhi?
Did the Tathagata have any Dharma to speak? and so on.
What does this illustrate?
It shows that the World-Honored One's realization of the truth is without any dharmas that can be grasped.
As for the term all dharmas, it is a conventional name in accordance with worldly convention, not the ultimate truth.

If both Dharma and non-Dharma are not grasped, then based on conventional truth it is called bodhi, but it is not a real entity. It is like saying that the great Brahma, the Buddhas and Tathagatas who realize bodhi, are said to be without attainment.
If there is nothing to be attained, how can the World-Honored One have various abilities?
The Tathagata's original vow is to universally benefit all beings:

When I attain perfect enlightenment and depart from all discrimination, without deliberate thought, until the end of sentient beings' births and deaths, according to their different kinds and desires, I will manifest in various forms and languages, but in the nature of all dharmas, there is nothing to be attained.
This attainment of enlightenment is also called the Dharma body, because the Dharma body of enlightenment is not to be attained.

Although there is no thought, still by the power of the original vow, boundless forms adorn his body, and he travels to all lands in the ten directions without obstruction. All who see or hear him are benefited.
The sage Subhuti, because enlightenment is unborn, answered with a hidden meaning, saying there is not the slightest dharma that the Tathagata has attained, not that he does not realize the unborn.
As the sutra says, The Dharma spoken by the Tathagata is all ungraspable and indescribable, neither Dharma nor not Dharma.
What is the meaning of this?
Non-arising means neither dharmas nor non-dharmas, because they are the realm of discrimination of dharmas and non-dharmas.
Ungraspable and inexpressible means there is no grasper or expounder, because one realizes the non-attainment of anything.
As the sutra says, It is called the holy one because of the characteristic of the unconditioned.ğŸ”½Unconditioned means the meaning of non-attainment.
Characteristic of the unconditioned means the meaning of the intrinsic nature of non-attainment.
Holy one means seeing the true meaning.
SubhÅ«ti further thought:
How much merit is there for those who deeply believe in the precepts and so forth in the sutra?
Therefore, it extensively clarifies the power and influence of upholding the Dharma.
The sutra says, SubhÅ«ti!
What do you think?
If one fills the trichiliocosm with the seven treasures and uses them for giving, and so forth, up to speaking for others... and so on.
Explaining it to others means skillfully expounding the principle of attainability and non-attainability in the two truths without error.

What is the teaching?
As a sÅ«tra says, The best of giving is called the giving of Dharma. Now this precious giving is included in material giving.

As the sutra says, Anuttara-samyak-sambodhi comes from this sutra, and all Buddha-tathagatas are born from this sutra.

Based on this Dharma gate, the mind attains nothing, and realizes the wondrous enlightenment of the principle of non-arising.

Moreover, it is said that the principle of the non-arising of all dharmas and so forth is the vow of speech. From this, the body of all merits is born. Because the vow of body is the perfect characteristic of karma, the transformation body is born.
For what reason does the giving of material goods only result in the great wealth and status of the human and heavenly realms, and not in the cause of Buddhahood?
The sutra says, The Buddha Dharma is not the Buddha Dharma, and this is called the Buddha Dharma.
What is the meaning of this?
The essence of all dharmas is empty and non-existent. If this is revealed, it is the Dharma body of the Buddha. Those who see it as having an essence have not yet realized the Dharma.
Based on this secret meaning, it is said to be not the Buddha Dharma.
If one knows that dharmas have no essence, and is enlightened, one is called a Buddha.
This Dharma belongs to the Buddha and not to other people. This is called the Buddha Dharma.
Because by upholding the true Dharma one understands the naturelessness of dharmas, practicing material giving cannot be like this. The merit of the Dharma gift is greater for this reason.
Next, there is doubt:
If the realized Dharma has no nature, how can the four noble fruits be accomplished?
One does not see in the world that a non-existent thing has a fruit.
In order to dispel this doubt, the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti!
What do you think?
Can a stream-enterer have the thought:
'I have attained the fruit of stream-entry'?
SubhÅ«ti said:
No, World-Honored One. It is like this.
Why is it called stream-entry?
Because one has entered the stream of non-attainment.
What is non-attainment?
Because there is no attainment in regard to forms and other sense objects.

The fifteen moments of thought are the path of seeing. Riding this toward the fruit is called the approach to that fruit. The sixteenth moment of thought is said to be abiding in the fruit. One is born in the heavens and among humans up to seven times.ğŸ”½Why seven births?
Because of the remaining seven fetters.
What are the seven bonds?
They are desire and greed, anger, attachment to form and formlessness, agitation, pride, and ignorance.
From this, one further cuts off the afflictions to be eliminated in the path of cultivation in the desire realm, up to the fifth category, called the path of the once-returner.
Here, two kinds of once-returners are further mentioned, namely heavenly and human.
The heavenly once-returner means that in the heavenly realm, either in one heaven or two heavens, one transmigrates through various families and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
The human once-returner means that in the human realm, either in this continent or other continents, one transmigrates through various families and attains parinirvÄá¹‡a.
Exhausting the sixth category is called abiding in this fruit, because one is born in this world once more.
In this way, in sequence, one further cuts off two categories, with one lifetime in between, and is about to attain parinirvÄá¹‡a, which is called the path of the non-returner.
Permanently severing the nine categories is called abiding in this fruit, because one is not reborn in the desire realm again.
In the same way, when one severs the desire for the first dhyÄna stage up to the ninth category of afflictions of the peak of existence, all are called the state of being an arhat.

This uninterrupted path is also called the concentration that is like a diamond, because it can eternally destroy the latent tendencies of the afflictions. When one reaches the path of liberation, it is called the knowledge of destruction, because it is simultaneously born with the attainment of the exhaustion of the contaminants.
In this way, one abides in the fruit of arhatship, because one should benefit oneself and others, and because one should be worshipped by all those who are attached to desire.
These four people all do not think, I can attain the fruit.
Why is this?
Because at the time of realization, there is nothing to attain.
As the sÅ«tra says, In reality, there is no dharma called stream-enterer, up to in reality, there is no dharma called arhat.
Why do they not wish to attain the fruit?
If this thought arises, there is the grasping of self, etc. Those who are free from the view of self do not have that grasping, and therefore it is said first.
The characteristic of the unconditioned is called the characteristic of emptiness.
SubhÅ«ti recounts his own attainment of non-thought, saying, The TathÄgata says I am foremost in the practice of non-dispute, and I am an arhat free from desire.
I do not have such thoughts.
What is the meaning of this?
If SubhÅ«ti practices non-dispute without realizing emptiness, why did the TathÄgata praise him as foremost?
The reason he is called foremost is because he realizes emptiness.
As the sÅ«tra says, SubhÅ«ti truly has no practice.
What is dispute?
It refers to afflictions.
Being free from those afflictions is called the concentration of non-dispute.
SubhÅ«ti abides in this concentration, and obstructions and disputes are all not present together, so he speaks conventionally of the practice of non-dispute, the practice of non-dispute.
Moreover, there is doubt:
If stream-enterers and others do not attain their own fruits, how is it that the World-Honored One, upon meeting DÄ«paá¹ƒkara Buddha, attained acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas?
In order to dispel this doubt, the sutra says, Subhuti!

Did the Tathagata in the past, when he was with Dipankara Buddha, grasp at anything in the Dharma?
Subhuti said:
No, it is not so.
World-Honored One. And so forth.
What does this clarify?
